> What does it mean? :)

@Binchan: We can say that Korean alphabet (Hangul) is the easiest system in the universe in learning, reading and writing since any one can learn how to read and write any sound in a day or two :p

But regarding language itself, maybe one of the hardest languages in the world to learn, listen and speak. 

Japanese and Korean languages are like brothers. It's not surprising it's too similar in every aspect since their bloods are sharing the same root from the beginning of their civilizations.

Writing Japanese language in Korean characters is straightforward. So is vice versa, though Japanese characters are lack of a few syllables. And even grammatically they're almost the same. 

But at a certain point (AD 1446), a man invented Hangul. lol. Before that time, we used Chinese characters.

When Japanese alphabet Hiragana invented??

> Ever heard of Teochew :3 Promised to be the hardest Chinese dialect to understand

@Binchan: A dialect of Jaeju Island in Korea was used as an encrypt verbal language for radio transmission during Korean War.. lol.

> German wiki about Min Nan 
@Binchan: Considering your quotation, I am getting doubtful about Jaeju dialect if it's a dialect or an independent language! lol.
Anyway I like Japanese Osaka dialect. :p https://youtu.be/iT1I1M8rcJg?t=32s

> @caryoscelus: topic-prominent is quite interesting.. And it amazed me that Singaporean English and Hungarian are in the list
@Binchan @caryoscelus : Amazing! Thanks for the info!
Agree. CPU and other circuits should also be opensourced if we consider the meltdown-spectre issues.

Can I have a pronunciation of those letters?

For ur info, several towns in Japan have Hangul characters in their ancient stone sculptures, though still not known from where. Some natives insist they themselves are from Korea hundreds years ago, others thought they're letters used only by their native priests, etc. The others have no idea at all.

IMHO, it's a bit far from the typical Hangul structure, though people could find Hangul-like syllables among those letters, but nonsense. (ex. 욜, 언, 에, 또, 엔, 욜) lol. Some are rotated counterclockwise, others are not. Especially the use of 'V' marks differs each case.

>  욜v, 언, 에, 또(띠), 엔, 욜
Anyway they match.. lol
That's very smart trick~ :)

@Binchan: That's great except that that lecture lacks how to read and write 'Batchim (tail consonants, such as 우유 -> 운융(oon yoong), etc.)'.

I told u~ anyone (over age 5) can learn Hangul in a day~ lol. 

What's funny in Korea nowadays is that some mothers are preventing their kids from learning Hangul. They try to postpone it as long as possible. Why? There's a study that learning written language (characters) too early rather decreases the growth of a certain part of the brain. 

They never praise their kids when the kids boast reading Hangul at 5 or 6 (sometimes even 8), but rather give a worry and hide books. lol.

Let's break the information wall by Hangul~! 

四聲 could be substituted with numeric characters or something..
@Loopback: Yep. I'm learning Chinese nowadays~! :)
@Binchan: Actually there's an hidden society in Korea where they are using encrypted version of Hangul. lol. May be one in million would know this in Korea.
Oh, the video lacks double consonants & vowels, too! Maybe that's just a bait product for the paid ones~ :(

The better thing u need to know about Hangul is the typing speed on the keyboard for the speech. It becomes like a stenography when typing a conversation comes to Hangul. lol. If typing with a special software, you can have a cup of water while typing 2 guys talking. If with a special keyboard? I'll not mention any more, 0_o);;;;;;

> Teochew has 八聲
@Binchan: Wow, with 8 sounds, you can literally speak like singing~!

> Yep, Tang poetry is still popular here and there are FM-radio for it

@Binchan: Poets written in Chinese letters were very common here till 1800s. But reading those poets in Korean can't be better at all than in Chinese. Because we don't have 四聲. 

For example, the 1st lines of 朱熹's 勸學時 and General Nami's 大丈夫歌 goes like this:
少年易老學難成
豆滿江派飮馬無

Reading in Korea? Like this: 소년이로,학난성(소녀니로,항난성 pronouce), 두만강파,음마무(두망강파,음마무) without any voice pitch variation but some pauses between meaningful phrases. There's no space for any gorgeous reading. :(
Try to read this :) 스프링 이즈 커밍. 왜더r 이즈 게팅 하터r.
Don't be in a hurry~ :) 워v시v환-쭝-구어/차이
Thanks! :)
@caryoscelus: `ㅓ = [ea]rth OR b[u]s`, `ㅗ = [o]il OR [oa]t`, `ㅜ = [woo]l OR [u]ltra`
That's right. It's mainly because of the foreign words such as `elevator` or `album`, etc. 'e' in those words has strong accent so that they began to replace 'ㅐ' during the period.

@Binchan: That is really amazing! Language is not only just a verbal technique, but also is a mirror of the history of those who used that language. Hope to reveal more and more secrets of the hidden histories in the languages! :)

> sepering isu kvming. wue(ai)dvr isu g(k)e(vi)ding ho(a)tvr.
@Binchan: right :) 서 & 스 have very different sounds. 서 is **se**rpent(Always having vowel behind it), 스 is **s**ports(No vowel). Whenever u pronounce ㅡ(으), you need to bite the front teeth. 
And `isu` seems to be `iz`. :)
So, `spring iz(no vowel) kvming. wuedvr iz G(not k. K is when ㄱ is used as the 3rd member like '덕'(duk, duck))eting hatvr`

> [Kim was an extremely gifted child and had picked up reading ability at eight months of age. At five years of age, he was able to read and comprehend The Great Learning and the Doctrine of the Mean.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kim_Si-seup)

@Binchan: I think in Hanyu's period learning Hanzi just `BEGAN` at age 4 to 6 but it doesn't mean that every kid could read and write, or even understand what he reads and create/explain what he learned/thought. The above Kim_Si-seup was prized by composing a poet in front of the king at his `age 5` and `called a genius` by people as recorded. (The king at this episode is King Sejong who invented Hangul. lol~)

In case of my mom, she memorized [Thousand_Character_Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thousand_Character_Classic) as well as could read and write at her age 5.

She was just a plain(?) genius in millions or thousands, `not an ordinary kid`. :)

> South Korean senior scholar, Daesan Kim Seok-jin (Korean Hangul: 대산 김석진), expressed the significance of Thousand Character Classic by contrasting the Western concrete science and the Asian metaphysics and origin-oriented thinking in which "it is the collected poems of nature of cosmos and reasons behind human life".

Yes, every 4 character set of 250 phrases is talking about the truth on the universe, the nature, the philosopy and the history. Awesome!

> its true that it's widely used for fortune. But from the wiki page:

>> the I Ching is an influential text read throughout the world, providing inspiration to the worlds of religion, psychoanalysis, business, literature, and art.

@Binchan: They're all about fortunes :) The reason why the westerners are crazy about I Ching is that it gives more details and inspiration rather than Tarot Cards and astrology. The user of the book should not fall into the vague concepts but should exactly use it as a fortune telling, though actually doing so is the violation of the rule of the spiritual world. Sadly most politicians and religious leaders are still heavily depends on the fortune telling such as I Ching, Tarot and astrology as if those strong people like Wilhelm had done before.

For ur reference, TCC or even comic books could be used as fortune-telling medium like I Ching by choosing random page number with bamboo fortune sticks, and translate what the chosen page describes. (PLZ DO NOT TRY ANY OF THESE! It's as dangerous as [Ouiza Board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ouija)!)

> providing inspiration to the worlds of religion, psychoanalysis, business, literature, and art.

@Binchan: I am a huge fan of the WuXia novels of [Jin Yong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jin_Yong). 

He is known as a master of I Ching, and in his novels many items in I Ching are used for various methods such as some titles of the martial art patterns or strategical tactics, etc. That is a huge difference between Jin Yong and other WuXia novelists. 

What I want to tell is that naming rule with Hanzi in his books is far sophisticated and very beautifully balanced between characters which used in naming various materials appearing in the novels. 

It means I Ching is composed by very highly intelligent scholars who are ones of the top class in literature, philosophy and arts about Asian culture. It's very unique characteristic of I Ching among other clumsy materials I mentioned before. That's why I Ching is so popular across the world.

But one should not be trapped in its beauty. It's simply a fortune telling reference book. :) Nothing more, nothing less. Just a luxury stuff.

@Binchan: If u haven't finished any books of his, u'd better not start any. :) Chinese government once announced that his books are Opium to the people (人民的鸦片). lol~ I absolutely agree to that though I hate Chinese communist government.

> I sometimes take screenshots as record

@Binchan: Manual screenshotting?

In my case, I used to do `$ xclip -sel c -o > quit-pyside.py;`.

To copy to clipboard, `$ cat quit-pyside.py | xclip -sel c;`.

`$ echo -n 'gpaste-client get 0' | wc -c;` -> `19`.
`$ echo -n 'xclip -sel c -o' | wc -c;` -> `15`. lol~
@Binchan: Is there any way to apply this in ssh terminal??
@Binchan: Oh... nono... I mean applying `xclip` or `gpaste-client` to SSH environment. :)

.
**Original filename**: `시진핑 비판 中 학자, 생방송 중 강제 연행 _ KBS뉴스(News)-jUPXu1Vonv4 (youtube (Arresting a Chinese scholar on air telephone talking with VOA while critisizing Xi Jin Ping 2018-08-03.mp4`
.
**Uploaded filename in URL**: `%20%20%20,%20%20%20%20%20_%20KBS(News)-jUPXu1Vonv4%20(youtube%20(Arresting%20a%20Chinese%20scholar%20on%20air%20telephone%20talking%20with%20VOA%20while%20critisizing%20Xi%20Jin%20Ping.mp4` -- **(In fact, they didn't escaped asian characters (means filename is not protected), but just replaced it with space characters `%20`. )**
.

> The upper case letters are 1/16 increments. The lower case letters are 1/256 increments. #e00 is 93.33...% full on red
0x0e=14(=15th out of 16 units which are 0 to 15). 15/16 * 100 = 93.75%, isn't it?
> \#ee000 is ... full on red
CORRECTION: #ee0000
> for instance, if you have a, you divide 10 by 15 and that comes out as 66.66...%.
0x0a=10(=11th out of 16 units). 11/16 * 100 = 68.75%, isn't it?

Is it true that Americans are the only people who use non-standard-unit in the world? 
.
I can't figure out how hot or cool it is with your numbers.
.
All I know is 32'F = 0'C(water-freezing), 100'F = 37.5'C(body temperature), so 69'F is in the middle somewhere between icy and body-warm.

echo 'scale=5; (69-32) / ((100-32) / 37.5)'|bc; # = 20.40'C

(69'F=Fahrenheit temperature to be converted. 32'F=freezing point. 100'F=37.5'C=body temperature)
.
The best season!

@ks: So we should take 212'F (=100'C) as a reference point rather than non-precise 100'F(=37.5'C), right?

|(100-32)/37.5|=1.81333|
|-|-|
|9/5|=1.80000|
|(212-32)/100|=1.80000|

Based on 212'F=100'C, 69'F = 20.55555'C, not 20.40'C.
.
Anyway my assumption was practical enough in spite of not being perfectly precise :)
